title: Savitri and Satyavan: The legend of the princess who outwitted Death - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What was Princess Savitri's initial decision regarding finding a husband?

options.label: A
options.text: She allowed her parents to choose a suitor for her.

options.label: B
options.text: She decided to wait for a man to approach her.

options.label: C
options.text: She determined to find a husband herself.

options.label: D
options.text: She chose to remain single.

multiple-choice.question: What was Satyavan's situation when Princess Savitri met him in the jungle?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a wealthy prince looking for a bride.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a poor man who had lost his parents.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a young man working tirelessly to support his blind and overthrown father.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a traveling sage sharing wisdom with the people.

options.label: A
options.text: That he was actually a prince in disguise.

options.label: B
options.text: That he had a hidden talent for music.

options.label: C
options.text: That he had only a year to live.

options.label: D
options.text: That he was destined for greatness.

multiple-choice.question: What was Princess Savitri's response to Yamraj, the God of Death, when he offered her a wish?

options.label: A
options.text: She asked for Satyavan's life to be spared.

options.label: B
options.text: She asked for wealth and power.

options.label: C
options.text: She asked for her father-in-law's sight to be restored.

options.label: D
options.text: She asked for the power to heal any illness.

multiple-choice.question: What was the final outcome for Princess Savitri and Satyavan?

options.label: A
options.text: They were separated forever by death.

options.label: B
options.text: They lived happily ever after, but without children.

options.label: C
options.text: Satyavan was returned to Savitri, and they lived united in their love.

options.label: D
options.text: Savitri was forced to marry another man.

title: Do personality tests work? - Merve Emre

options.text: Carl Jung and Isabel Briggs Myers

options.label: B
options.text: Katherine Cook Briggs and Isabel Briggs Myers

options.label: C
options.text: Katherine Cook Briggs and Carl Jung

options.label: D
options.text: Isabel Briggs Myers and Sigmund Freud

multiple-choice.question: What is a major problem with the way personality tests are constructed?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too long and time-consuming

options.label: B
options.text: They are based on different sets of metrics to define personality

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used by individuals, not by schools or companies

options.label: D
options.text: They are too expensive to administer

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult for people to be objective when answering self-reported personality test questions?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are trying to be dishonest

options.label: B
options.text: Because they subconsciously aim to please the person or institution asking the question

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not intelligent enough to understand the questions

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are too busy to answer the questions carefully

multiple-choice.question: What has research suggested about personality?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a stable, measurable feature of an individual

options.label: B
options.text: That it shifts during key periods, such as school years or when starting work

options.label: C
options.text: That it is only influenced by genetics, not by upbringing or life experiences

options.label: D
options.text: That it is the same across all cultures and societies

multiple-choice.question: Why is it problematic for institutions to use personality tests to make decisions about hiring or education?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the tests are too expensive to administer

options.label: B
options.text: Because the tests are not widely used

options.label: C
options.text: Because the results do not predict how a person will perform in a specific role

options.label: D
options.text: Because the tests are only used by individuals, not by institutions

title: Climate change will displace millions. Here's how we prepare - Colette Pichon Battle

options.label: B
options.text: 180 million

options.label: C
options.text: 250 million

options.label: D
options.text: 500 million

options.label: B
options.text: Human activities that release CO2 emissions

options.label: C
options.text: An economic system that prioritizes extraction and consumption

options.label: D
options.text: Natural disasters

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: Developing new technologies to reduce CO2 emissions

options.label: B
options.text: Restructuring social and economic systems to prioritize regeneration and human liberty

options.label: C
options.text: Building sea walls to protect coastal communities

options.label: D
options.text: Implementing stricter climate regulations

options.label: B
options.text: Establishing a new social attitude that sees migration as a benefit

options.label: C
options.text: Investing in temporary solutions to address immediate needs

options.label: D

options.label: D
options.text: It is a metaphor for the speaker's fear of death.

title: Building the world's largest (and most controversial) power plant - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the world's largest hydroelectric plant, which is capable of producing more energy than any other power plant on Earth?

options.text: Three Gorges Dam

options.label: B
options.text: Itaipu Dam

options.label: C
options.text: Inga Falls Dam

options.label: D
options.text: Yangtze River Dam

multiple-choice.question: How does a hydroelectric dam produce electricity?

options.label: A
options.text: By burning fossil fuels to power a generator

options.label: B
options.text: By redirecting a river's natural flow through a penstock, which turns the blades of a turbine attached to a generator

options.label: C
options.text: By harnessing the energy of the sun to power a solar panel

options.label: D
options.text: By using nuclear reactions to generate electricity

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the major human costs of building the Three Gorges Dam?

options.label: A
options.text: The construction of the dam took over 20 years to complete

options.label: B
options.text: The dam's reservoir flooded over 600 square kilometers of land upstream, displacing roughly 1.4 million people

options.label: C
options.text: The dam's construction was highly expensive and put a strain on China's economy

options.label: D
options.text: The dam's location made it difficult to transport materials and equipment

options.label: B
options.text: The size of the dam and the depth of the water

options.label: C
options.text: The location of the dam and the type of materials used to build it

options.label: D
options.text: The age of the dam and the number of people it employs

multiple-choice.question: Why was the Itaipu Dam able to outperform the Three Gorges Dam in terms of energy output, despite being smaller?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has more turbines than the Three Gorges Dam

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is located in a region with more consistent water flow, allowing it to generate power more consistently

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is newer and more modern than the Three Gorges Dam

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is located in a country with more advanced technology

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Being present and truly listening to the other person

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Go with the flow

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Listening

options.label: C
options.text: Asking questions

options.label: D
options.text: Being knowledgeable about a wide range of topics

multiple-choice.question: What is the final rule of having a good conversation, according to the speaker?

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Why is pneumonia so dangerous? - Eve Gaus and Vanessa Ruiz

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the alveoli in the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter out pathogens from the air we breathe

options.label: B
options.text: To facilitate the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the air and bloodstream

options.label: C
options.text: To produce mucus to trap invaders

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.text: It is a type of white blood cell that defends against foreign organisms

options.label: B
options.text: It is a mechanism that traps invaders and carries them toward the mouth to be coughed out

options.label: C
options.text: It is a type of bacteria that causes pneumonia

options.label: D
options.text: It is a type of virus that causes pneumonia

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common symptom of pneumonia?

options.label: B
options.text: Rapid breathing

options.label: C
options.text: Coughing up blood

options.label: D
options.text: Fever

multiple-choice.question: What can happen if the body enters a sustained fight against an infection it can't maintain?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Organs start shutting down, causing shock and sometimes death

options.label: D
options.text: The infection is cleared out quickly

multiple-choice.question: How can pneumonia be prevented?

options.label: B

options.text: By smoking and avoiding vaccines

options.label: D
options.text: By taking antibiotics regularly

title: Are all of your memories real? - Daniel L. Schacter

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the study where participants were told they got lost in a shopping mall as children, even though they didn't?

options.label: A
options.text: None of the participants believed they got lost in the mall.

options.label: B
options.text: A quarter of the participants produced false memories of getting lost in the mall.

options.label: C
options.text: Half of the participants remembered getting lost in the mall.

options.label: D
options.text: All participants had vivid memories of getting lost in the mall.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of suggestibility in memory, as shown in the mall study?

options.label: A
options.text: Incorporating information from personal experiences into memories.

options.label: B
options.text: Incorporating information from outside sources, like other people or the news, into personal recollections.

options.label: C
options.text: Forgetting important details of a memory.

options.label: D
options.text: Misattributing information from one context to another.

multiple-choice.question: What happened in the study where participants were shown an image of a magnifying glass and then told to imagine a lollipop?

options.label: A
options.text: Participants frequently recalled seeing the lollipop but not the magnifying glass.

options.label: B
options.text: Participants frequently recalled seeing both the magnifying glass and the lollipop.

options.label: C
options.text: Participants struggled to link the objects to the correct context.

options.label: D
options.text: Participants forgot both the magnifying glass and the lollipop.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the study where participants were asked about their views on marijuana legalization in 1973 and 1982?

options.label: A
options.text: Participants' views on marijuana legalization remained consistent over time.

options.label: B
options.text: Participants who changed their views on marijuana legalization tended to recall their original views accurately.

options.label: C
options.text: Participants who changed their views on marijuana legalization tended to recall their original views as being more in line with their current views.

options.label: D
options.text: Participants' views on marijuana legalization had no impact on their memories.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of the fallibility of memory in a courtroom setting?

options.label: A
options.text: Jurors may be more likely to convict a defendant based on eyewitness testimony.

options.label: B
options.text: Jurors may be less likely to convict a defendant based on eyewitness testimony.

options.label: C
options.text: Leading questions from police interrogations could result in incorrect identifications or unreliable confessions.

options.label: D
options.text: Judges may be more likely to rule in favor of the prosecution.

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What are the three essential components of liberal democracy?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Acceptance of societal divisions, seeking common ground, and the rule of law

options.label: C
options.text: Free markets, limited government, and individual freedom

multiple-choice.question: How do modern populists view institutions such as courtrooms, free press, and national constitutions?
